title: Slaughtering with a serrated knife
vignette: A shochet discovers small nicks on his knife after using it.

options.text: The meat is invalid; the cut may have torn.
If the nick is minor, the slaughter stands.

title: Blood covered by someone else
vignette: A passerby covers the blood of a fowl before the slaughterer can do so.

options.text: The mitzvah is lost and the meat remains kosher.
He should slaughter again to perform the command himself.

title: Stunning before slaughter
vignette: To minimize pain, an electric stunner is used prior to shechita.

options.text: Permissible if the animal remains alive for the cut.
Forbidden; stunning disqualifies the slaughter.

title: Bird found decapitated
vignette: A chicken is discovered headless in the yard with no witness to how it died.

options.text: Assume improper slaughter and forbid eating.
Presume it was slaughtered correctly and permit it.

title: Doubtful stabbing during shechita
vignette: While cutting, the knife may have pressed instead of sliced for a moment.

options.text: Any doubt invalidates the meat.
If most of the cut was smooth, it is allowed.

title: Non-Jew assisting with slaughter
vignette: A gentile holds the animal steady while the Jew slaughters.

options.text: Valid as long as the Jew performs the cut.
Invalid; only Jews may handle the animal.

title: Liver examined after salting
vignette: The liver is checked for worms after it was salted with other meat.

options.text: If worms are found, all meat must be discarded.
Only the liver is suspect; the rest is fine.

title: Mixing kosher and non-kosher fat
vignette: Rendered fat from a non-kosher animal accidentally mixes with permitted fat.

options.text: Any amount contaminates the whole pot.
Follow the sixty-to-one rule; nullify if small enough.

title: Found needle in cow's stomach
vignette: During inspection, a needle is discovered stuck in the stomach lining.

options.text: The animal is kosher unless the organ was punctured.
The mere presence forbids the meat.

title: Passing meat through a non-kosher oven
vignette: Cooked meat briefly touches a tray in a non-kosher restaurant kitchen.

options.text: It absorbs forbidden taste and must be discarded.
Quick contact doesn't matter; wipe it off and eat.

title: Selling hindquarters to non-Jews
vignette: The sciatic nerve is difficult to remove, so the hind portion is sold to gentiles.

options.text: Permissible to sell if not eaten by Jews.
Avoid trade that might lead Jews to eat it.

title: Tithing obligations for domesticated birds
vignette: Someone raises doves at home and wonders if they require tithing like livestock.

options.text: Yes; designate a portion as sacred.
No formal tithing applies to household birds.

title: Using animal hide for a scroll
vignette: A hide from a non-slaughtered animal is processed into parchment for sacred texts.

options.text: Acceptable if tanned properly.
Only hides from kosher slaughter may be used.

title: Mixing meat and fish in one dish
vignette: A stew accidentally combines chicken pieces with fish fillets.

options.text: Eat it; the combination is safe though unconventional.
Avoid eating due to health and custom concerns.

title: Feeding torn meat to animals
vignette: Meat from an improper slaughter is fed to household pets.

options.text: Allowed; no prohibition on benefit.
Better to bury it out of respect.
